Award.AwardTitle: Disorder and Dynamics in Silicate and Aluminosilicate Liquids, Glasses, and Crystals Relevant to Geochemical Processes: Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Studies
Award.AbstractNarration:
The focus of this research program is the atomic-scale structure and dynamics of the silicate minerals, glasses and magmas that are at the center of most geological processes, from those taking place at the Earth's surface to those in the planet's deep interior. The ultimate goal of this work is to provide better fundamental understanding, and eventually better prediction, of the material properties that ultimately control complex processes in nature, many of which have enormous impacts on people and on society. For the two-year grant period, one emphasis will be on the effects of high pressure on the structure and properties of silicate melts that represent magmas in the Earth, and hence are tied to many geological processes including the formation and eruption of volcanoes. A second major activity will be further development and application of methods to measure the distribution of minor elements in some of the most important silicate minerals in the Earth's crust and mantle, in order to improve models that describe their chemical behavior in nature, and thus better our ability to glean clues about geological evolution from natural samples. Results and methods developed in this project should continue to be of major interest outside of the Earth sciences, particularly for researchers working to develop and optimize silicate glasses and ceramics for advanced technologies, such as materials for data processing and transmission, computer displays, substrates for photovoltaics, fuel cells, and many other applications. Education is central to this project, since most of the research will be part of the training of Ph.D. and undergraduate students on their ways to careers in science and engineering.

The approach taken in this research is to identify important problems where critical details of short- to intermediate-range structure are needed and can be elucidated by laboratory measurements, collect accurate data on synthetic or natural materials, and determine the consequences of the results for key chemical and physical parameters. The most important experimental approach that will be used is solid-state Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, which can reveal quantitative details about the structure around many of the components common in minerals and magmas, such as silicon, aluminum, oxygen, phosphorus, and sodium. A variety of compositions of glasses (representing the high temperature molten materials in natural magma systems) and crystalline materials will be synthesized, and measurements made of how their structures change with composition, temperature and pressure. One particular emphasis will be to continue to extend the applicability of NMR, traditionally used to look at abundant constituents of non-magnetic materials, to minor and even trace components and to materials containing substantial amounts of magnetic components. These data should be particularly important in helping to develop more accurate, physically-based models of mineral and magma properties and behavior, which are especially important in the Earth sciences, as many processes take place in regimes of temperature, pressure, and time that are inaccessible to direct observation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most of the Earth and other terrestrial planets is made up of silicate and oxide rocks and minerals, many of which have formed from hot, molten liquids (magmas). Crystalline, molten, and glassy silicate and oxide materials are thus at the center of most of the processes that have formed the planet and continue to affect human activities through earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, formation of deposits of natural resources, and the landscapes in which we all live. Our fundamental understanding of such materials, and our abilities to predict and model their properties and behaviors at the high temperatures and pressures of the Earth’s interior, require detailed knowledge of their atomic-scale structures. The general goal of this project has been to quantify the structures of silicate and oxide minerals and glasses (quenched melts) of importance to major geological processes in the Earth. We have focused on materials in which the atomic arrangements are highly disordered, and thus often difficult to measure with common structural tools such as X-ray diffraction. Our primary experimental tool is Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR), which provides detailed and quantitative information about the short-range (atomic and molecular-scale) structure around atoms of many of the chemical elements that are most abundant in the Earth, including silicon (Si), aluminum (Al), oxygen (O), sodium (Na), and phosphorus (P). 

 

The research supported by this grant has lead to important new discoveries about the structures of silicate glasses that inform us about properties of high temperature melts and magmas in nature. For example, we showed that conventional models of chemical composition on melt structure, which describe how cations (positively charged ions) and anions (negatively charged ions) join to form stiff, viscous networks, are much too simple in detail and that previously unseen structural groups can be important and may have major effects on melt properties. Examples include the presence of Al cations with five and six O neighbors instead of four, and of loosely bonded “non-bridging” oxygen ions in compositions where these were thought to be absent.  We have also focused on the effects of pressure on melt structure, as magmas in the modern Earth are usually formed at depths of up to about 100 km, where pressures reach about 30,000 times that of the planet’s surface. Using a new experimental approach, we have shown that many previous experiments on pressure effects on structures give only minimum estimates of the actual changes. Our new data show that structure-based models of melt properties, even for this relatively “modest” pressures, will need to be significantly revised.

 

We also made a major effort in developing solid-state NMR methods for determining the distributions of elements in oxide crystal structures, when magnetic ions (having unpaired electron spins) are present. This is opening the doorway to a wide range of applications of this method to many more types of solid materials that have long been thought to be inaccessible to NMR studies. For materials most interesting to the Earth sciences, these include transition metal ions such as iron, nickel, and cobalt, and the strategically critical rare earth elements. We have reported major progress in this area with a variety of minerals important both in the Earth and in advanced technologies, including olivines, garnets, bridgmanite, and rare earth phosphates. In the latest stage of this ongoing work, we progressed from minerals with relatively low (0.5 to 5 %) concentrations of such elements to pure phase minerals such as pure Fe, Ni, and Co olivines and pyroxenes, as well as to glasses with over 25 wt% of transition metal oxides.

 

Much of the research supported by this grant has been of major interest in fields outside of the Earth sciences, especially for advanced technological materials, both crystalline and glassy, as well as to the solid-state NMR community in physical chemistry. Education and outreach have been central to the work funded by this grant. It helped support the research of three Ph.D. students. This research has thus been a critical part of the training and scientific career development for all of the student participants.
